channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Summer is calling… Perl role in Malta
item.description: Our client is an international financial company with offices around the world. With a global presence and the kind of growth that would make a beanstalk blush, they’re looking to expand their team. If you’re a Perl programmer with a side interest in online trading, you’ll be a natural in this role.

item.title: Forget the carrot and stick! Perl role in London
item.description: As a company at the top of their game, our client is looking for a Perl developer who is similarly eager to be the best. You’ll thrive in an environment where you work independently and in teams, and you enjoy writing code with a variety of languages. Your knowledge of JS and experience with frameworks like React will round out your understanding of MySQL and NoSQL databases like Google BigTable.

item.title: NLP is all right by me! Perl, Python, NLP role in Amsterdam
item.description: Our client’s goal is human level parsing. They’re on the hunt for an NLP Engineer who has strong Perl and Python. Add in your experience with text processing, Artificial Intelligence, or Computational Logistics, and they’ll be waving you over to their table.

item.title: Wanted: Senior Perl developers with good karma. Remote Perl within UK, South Africa and Switzerland
item.description: Our client is a multinational fundraising group that works with thousands of charities to provide cloud-based management tools, a dedicated social fundraising platform, and a secure channel for charities to receive funds. If your Modern Perl game is on point and you have experience with payment systems, we want to hear from you.

item.title: Someone left the awesome job machine on again… UK remote Perl job
item.description: Perl programmers, lean in — this is the opportunity for you if your happy place is at home in your fuzzy bunny slippers. The role is 100% remote friendly for those located in the UK, so kick back and enjoy your commute-free existence. The client is interested in anyone with experience building web apps in Perl, using one of the major Perl frameworks.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great CPAN modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: Weekly Challenge 127
item.description: To the point blog post sharing the internals of the weekly contributions in Perl. Keep it up.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 127: Disjoint Conflict
item.description: Roger has been sharing code in multiple languages every week. Perl looked the simplest in all, I must admit.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 127
item.description: Great demonstration of PDL. It is always a pleasure to see the use of PDL. Keep it up.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 127: no need for coffee
item.description: Short and sweet Raku solutions shared by Luca. Incredible.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 127: Disjoint Sets and Conflict Intervals
item.description: Cute and short solutions in Perl and Raku. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: TWC 127: Intersection on a Sunday Afternoon
item.description: I read Jared's blog for the interesting stories. He is so good at sharing a solution with a story around it. Keep it up.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge #127
item.description: James used his domain knowledge whilst dealing with the weekly challenge. Thanks for your contributions.

item.title: PWC127 - Conflict Intervals
item.description: Great example to help you learn Raku. Cool translation of Perl code. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: PWC127 - Disjoint Sets
item.description: Flavio plays with Raku consistently and it shows in the quality of his contributions. Keep it up.

item.title: Multiple Sets of Interval Training: The Weekly Challenge #127
item.description: Dave makes good use of CPAN. Thanks for promoting CPAN.

item.title: Time Out-of-Joint — at Set Intervals
item.description: Task analysis is the main attraction of this blog post for me. It makes the code easy to read. Great contributions. Thanks.

item.title: Disjoint Conflict with Raku and Perl
item.description: Arne's blog always teaches me something new in Raku. This time, it was "so". Thanks for your contributions.

item.title: Conflicting Lists and Intervals
item.description: Adam's ability to make a difficult task look simple is rare. This is pure talent. Keep it up.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 127: Conflict Intervals
item.description: Abigail shared something new in this solution with "my sub intersects". Thanks for enlighting us.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 127: Disjoint Sets
item.description: Abigail surprised me once again with %_. Never used it before, thanks for sharing.

item.title: Perl Review - Perl Weekly Challenge - 125
item.description: Perl Solutions Review by Colin Crain.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 127
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Disjoint Sets" and "Conflict Intervals" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 128
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "Maximum Sub-Matrix" and "Minimum Platforms". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: The ephemeral miniconf - Speaker announcement
item.description: Speaker announcement: Mark Gardner

item.title: unit sub MAIN (...);
item.description: How to define command line options in Raku

item.title: Pod::Markdown and Pod::Markdown::Github for the win!
item.description: Convert POD documentation to Markdown with one (or two) command-line tools.

item.title: Frenemies part 2: What a difference a (Perl) module makes
item.description: Mark continues his mashup article mixing Perl and Raku.

item.title: Perl 2020 retrospective
item.description: What were the Perl-related highlights of 2020 for you?

item.title: The ephemeral miniconf
item.description: The ephemeral miniconf is a Perl and Raku virtual miniconf that will take place in Zoom on the 18 November 2021.

item.title: #527 - New school-year?
item.description:
Hi there,

The number of posts has been really low in the last couple of weeks. I really hope that with the new school-year in the northern hemisphere, we'll see an uptick in Perl-related content.

Other:

I just saw a Tweet explaining why the person does not wear a mask. He writes because he is vaccinated he isn't likely to be infected and he accepts the risks. Well, I really try to avoid arguing with strangers on the Internet so I did not write to him, but basically he said that he accepts the risk of endangering others.

In reality he spread two types of viruses. Potentially he spreads the Covid19 virus and for sure he spreads the idea that not caring for others is acceptable. For one, people who are unsure about the masks, seeing him without a mask will more likely stop wearing masks too.

Get vaccinated if you can and wear a mask when among people!

Enjoy your week!
item.dc:subject: list of tags?
